E.AnalysisAP09TakingActionQuestion: Useful Measures to Reduce Overdue Invoices
E.LateFeePercentDescription: Enter the average late fee percentage (in decimal number, e.g. 0.015 for 1.5%) per month. Default is 0.02 (2%) per month.
E.TouchlessOrdersDefineManualActivities: Deselect activities which should not be used for the calculation of 'Touchless Orders'. The table on the right can be used to identify 'always manual' activities.
E.overdueInvoicesRatioDescription: The percentage of invoices that are not yet paid at a certain time (default setting is until today)
E.AnalysisAP06Heading: Monitor your Payment Behavior to optimize liquidity
E.AnalysisAP06MotivationText1: Payment behavior for accounts payable describes the way in which a company fulfills its debt obligations towards its suppliers.
E.AnalysisAP06MotivationText2: Ideally, invoices should be paid on the due date or if applicable and beneficial on the cash discount date. Incoming invoices paid too early result in an unnecessary decrease in liquidity.
E.AnalysisAP06MotivationText3: Late payments, on the other hand, can cause dunning penalties and additional manual effort.
E.AnalysisAP06MotivationText4: Use this analysis to gain insights into your company's payment behavior in order to optimize liquidity management.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText1: Ratio of Invoice Value that is paid before the due date or the next cash discount date.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText2: A buffer of 1 day is applied to every due and cash discount date before and after to account for weekends.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText3:
The buffer can be changed in the Settings sheet.

For example, if an invoice without any cash discounts dates is due in 30 days, then anything paid in less than 29 days would be considered too early.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText4: In case of an additional cash discount date in 15 days, then anything paid in less than 14 days and between 16 and 29 days would be considered too early.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText5: Ratio of Invoice Value that is paid after the due date. A buffer of 1 day is applied to every due date to account for weekends.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText6:
The buffer can be changed in the Settings sheet.

For example, if an invoice is due in 30 days, then anything paid later than 31 days would be considered too late.
E.AnalysisAP06KPIText7: Open invoices are excluded from the analysis.
E.AnalysisAP06RootCauses1: Average Number of Days Paid Too Early and Too Late
E.AnalysisAP06RootCauses2: Number of Days Paid Too Early and Paid Too Late
E.AnalysisAP06RootCausesInfo1: Activities that are considered change activities can be defined in the settings sheet.
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionHeading: What are useful measures to optimize Payment Behavior?
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionMeasure1: Reduce the number of unnecessary early payments
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionMeasure5: Pay invoice with high value manually
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionObjective1: Avoid opportunity costs of early payments
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionObjective3: Avoid penalty fees and dunning costs
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionObjective5: Guarantee on time payment for critical invoices
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation1: - Identify and analyse the number of invoices that are paid before the next given payment date, be it a cash discount or a final due date
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation2: - Address the departments responsible for this payment behavior in order to make payments as late as possible for a given payment date
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation3: - If a cash discounts is offered, evaluate whether it makes sense to take it
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation4: - Calculate the annualized interest rate of forgoing a cash discount by taking the amount of discount divided by the discounted amount multiplied by the number of days paid earlier over the year (360)
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation5: - Compare this annualized rate with the costs of capital
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation6: - If the annualized rate is higher, it is worth taking the cash discount even by taking out additional debt
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation7: - Late payments might improve your working capital. However, they can also result in fees, additional effort as well as damaged supplier relationships
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation8: - Identify the number of invoices that are paid late and evaluate their impact on a supplier's relationship as well as costs
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation9: - If necessary, negotiate new payment terms with suppliers to increase your payment period
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation10: - Use SAP's Automatic Payment Program to perform payment runs more frequently
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation11: - Identify invoices above a certain high invoice value
E.AnalysisAP06TakingActionImplementation12: - Exclude those invoices from payments runs and instead pay them manually to ensure on time payment
E.setBuffer: Define the amount of days that should be set as a buffer before and after cash discount dates and after due dates.
E.setChangeActivities: Define the activities that are considered change activities.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent3: Working capital loss by early payments
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo1: Invoices paid too early represent a unnecessary reduction in liquidity. The capital could have been used elsewhere in the organisation and results in a working capital loss for the time paid too early.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo2: This number is calculated by taking the invoice value of all early payments multiplied by the Weighted Average Cost of Capital multiplied by the average amount of days paid too early over the year (365).
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent4: Manual effort to deal with dunning
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent8: Business impact of manual dunning effort
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo3: Late payments might result in dunning. Processing and handling these incidents causes manual effort.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo4: This number is calculated by taking the invoice positions of all late payments multiplied by the ratio of invoices that involve dunning multiplied by the costs per minute multiplied by the time required.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo5: Late payments might result in penalty fees.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo6: This is number is calculated by taking the invoice value of all late payments multiplied by a potential late penalty fee.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent13: Working capital gain by Late Payments (offset)
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo7: Invoices paid too late represent an extension of liquidity. The capital can be used elsewhere in the organisation and results in a working capital gain for the time paid too late.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo8: This number is calculated by taking the invoice value of all late payments multiplied by the Weighted Average Cost of Capital multiplied by the average amount of days paid too late over the year (365).
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent14: Business impact of early and late payments
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo9: This number is calculated the following: Manual effort to deal with duns + Late penalty fees - Working capital gain
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponent17: Overall business impact of unfavorable payment behavior
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo10: This number represents the overall business impact of unfavorable payment behavior in terms of early and late payments and the potential improvement.
E.AnalysisAP06BusinessCaseComponentInfo11: Important: This number is based on average days. Looking at individual cases will result in different values.

E.AR01ExplanationAmountA:
Paid too late/Paid too early/Paid on-time/:

The KPI "Payment Behavior - Paid too late/Paid too early/Paid on-time" is calculated over all invoice positions
E.AR01ExplanationAmountB: and is defined as the percentage of cleared invoices, that have been paid after/before or within their due dates. Additionally, you can select a buffer in days in the settings sheet which is added to the due date.
E.AR01ExplanationAmountC: Invoice positions that have not yet been cleared are not taken into account in the calculation.
E.AR02ExplanationDunningRateA:
Rate Dunned Invoices:

The KPI "Dunning Report - Rate Dunned Invoices" is calculated over all invoice positions
E.AR02ExplanationDunningRateB: and is defined as the percentage of invoices, that have been dunned (at least dunning level 1).
E.AR02settingsText: Define the number of days since the last overdue notice (for the pie chart 'Last Overdue Notices' in the sheet 'Overview')
E.AR06ExplanationDate: Please select the start date for the aging analysis below:
E.AR06ExplanationDimension: Please select a the dimension for the aging analysis below:
E.AR06SettingsDateText: Select the date which you want to use as calculation date (start date) for the aging analysis.
E.AR07ExplanationBPDSOa:
Best Possible Days Sales Outstanding:

The KPI Best Possible Days Sales Outstanding (BPDSO) is calculated for every invoice position
E.AR07ExplanationBPDSOb: and is defined as the number of days defined as Net Payment Terms Period in your payment terms. You can select the date, which should be used as calculation start date in the settings sheet.
E.AR07ExplanationBPDSOc: When aggregating several invoice positions, the individual invoice positions are weighted with their gross invoice value.
E.AR07ExplanationDSOa:
Days Sales Outstanding:

The KPI Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) is calculated for every invoice position
E.AR07ExplanationDSOb: and is defined as the number of days between a starting date, which can be selected in the settings sheet, and the clearing date of an invoice.
E.AR07ExplanationDSOc: Invoice positions that have not yet been cleared are not taken into account in the calculation.
E.AR07ExplanationDSOd: When aggregating several invoice positions, the individual invoice positions are weighted with their gross invoice value.
E.AR07ExplanationOverdueDSOa:
Overdue Days Sales Outstanding:

The KPI Overdue Days Sales Outstanding is calculated for every invoice position that was only cleared after its due date.
E.AR07ExplanationOverdueDSOb: It is defined as the number of days between the due date and the clearing date of an invoice.
E.AR07ExplanationOverdueDSOc: Invoice positions that have not yet been cleared are not taken into account in the calculation.
E.AR07ExplanationOverdueDSOd: When aggregating several invoice positions, the individual invoice positions are weighted with their gross invoice value.

E.AnalysisAR07Heading: Monitor Days Sales Outstanding to optimize cash inflow
E.AnalysisAR07MotivationText1: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) is the average amount of time that a receivable is outstanding. DSO is a vital indicator of healthy cash flow and efficient receivable management.
E.AnalysisAR07MotivationText2: Ideally, DSO should be consistent with a company’s credit policy, represented by the Best Possible DSO.
E.AnalysisAR07MotivationText3: If DSO is too high, it could be a sign that a business lacks stringent account collection procedures and as a result is losing money for every overdue day.
E.AnalysisAR07MotivationText4: Use this app to monitor DSO over time and find root causes for unfavorable DSO in order to take the right actions.
E.AnalysisAR07KPIText2: The KPI Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) is calculated for every invoice position and is defined as the number of days between a starting date, which can be selected in the settings sheet, and the clearing date of an invoice.
E.AnalysisAR07KPIText3: Invoice positions that have not yet been cleared are not taken into account in the calculation.</br></br>
E.AnalysisAR07KPIText4: When aggregating several invoice positions, the individual invoice positions are weighted with their gross invoice value.
E.AnalysisAR07KPIText6: The KPI Best Possible Days Dales Outstanding is calculated for every invoice position and is defined as the number of days defined as Net Payment Terms Period in your payment terms.
E.AnalysisAR07KPIText7: You can select the date, which should be used as the calculation start date in the settings sheet.</br></br>
E.AnalysisAR07RootCausesKPIText2: The KPI Overdue Days Sales Outstanding is calculated for every invoice position that was only cleared after its due date. It is defined as the number of days between the due date and the clearing date of an invoice.
E.AnalysisAR07RootCausesKPIText3: Invoice positions that have not yet been cleared are not taken into account in the calculation.</br></br>When aggregating several invoice positions, the individual invoice positions are weighted with their gross invoice value.
E.AnalysisAR07RootCausesKPIText5: Opportunity Costs of Late Payments are the forgone return of overdue payments.
E.AnalysisAR07RootCausesKPIText6: Costs are calculated by taking the value of each overdue invoice item multiplied by the Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC), defined in the settings sheet, multiplied by the Overdue DSO over the year.
E.ClickHereForMoreInfoDSO: Click here for more information about reasons that lead to unfavorable Days Sales Outstanding
E.AnalysisAR07RootCauses3: - Customers being unsatisfied with a product or service
E.AnalysisAR07RootCauses5: - Salespeople offering longer terms of payment to drive increased sales
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionHeading: What are useful measures to optimize Days Sales Outstanding?
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionMeasure2: Perform due diligence when granting lines of credit
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionMeasure3: Set stricter payment terms for late-paying customers
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionObjective1: Make it easier for customers to pay
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionObjective3: Avoid late payments in the future
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionObjective5: Avoid future problems and cap costs
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation1: - Gather feedback from current Customers in terms of their preferable payment method
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation2: - Weight up the pros and cons associated with each payment method such as room for error, privacy or fees
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation3: - Allow payment methods such as cash, direct debit, bank transfer, credit cards, PayPal or digital currencies etc.
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation4: - Perform thorough credit checks when engaging with new customers before extending credit
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation5: - Directly address the top 10 customers with the highest number of Overdue DSO causing the highest opportunity costs to accelerate payment
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation6: - If unsuccessful review the current terms and conditions for those late-paying customers
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation7: - Enforce shorter periods of payment or request staggered, up-front payments
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation9: - Analyze whether you have a lot of late paying customers
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation10: - Send out reminders consistently and in a timely manner
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation11: - Increment the number of dunning runs to twice or thrice a week
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation12: - Compare the following-up costs plus the lost interest on the amount extended as credit against the value of the customer
E.AnalysisAR07TakingActionImplementation13: - Consider other factors such as length of relationship or strategic importance

E.supportedUnitsText1: The tables below show the units of measure for the default and the confirmed time for an activitiy used in the data set.
E.supportedUnitsText2: For not supported units no conversion has been defined and therefore the performance for these activities will not be calculated.
E.columnsSetupTime: Columns for the default and confirmed value for the setup time
E.columnsDefaultSetupTime: Select the columns in which the default value and the corresponding unit for the setup time is stored.
E.columnsConfirmedSetupTime: Select the columns in which the confirmed value and the corresponding unit for the setup time is stored.
E.columnsMachine: Columns for the default and confirmed value for the machine time
E.columnsDefaultMachine: Select the columns in which the default value and the corresponding unit for the machine time are stored.
E.columnsConfirmedMachine: Select the columns in which the confirmed value and the corresponding unit for the machine time are stored.
E.buttonTextPP02_1_0: Setup time is the time needed to prepare a machine/system so it is able to perform a certain operation.
E.buttonTextPP02_1_1: The KPI target attainment for the setup time is given by the default value divided by the confirmend value of an operation. E.g. a confirmed time of 10 min with 5 min default time will result in an attainment of 50%.
E.buttonTextPP02_1_2:
Over multiple values the average is taken.

Notice: Only operations with an given default value will be taken into account. Are both default and confirmed value zero no attainment will be calculated.
E.buttonPP00: Information on the calculation of adherence to schedules
E.buttonTextPP00_1:
The adherence to schedules is calculated as difference (on a date basis) between the scheduled and the actual start and finish of production.

Used columns:
E.buttonTextPP00_2:
- Adherence Start: AFKO.GSTRS and AFKO.GSTRI

- Adherence End: AFKO.GLTRS and AFKO.GLTRI (alternative AFPO.LTRMI if AFKO.GLTRI is not used)
E.buttonTextPP03_0: Machine time is the time spent using mechanical equipment during an operation.
E.buttonTextPP03_1: The KPI target attainment for the machine time is calculated via this formula: default value per unit * (yield + scrap) / confirmed activity time.
E.buttonTextPP03_2: E.g. a default time of 3 min per unit, four units yield, one unit scrap and 20 min confirmed activity time result in an attainment of 75%.
E.buttonTextPP03_3:
Over multiple values the average is taken.

Notice: Only operations with an given default value will be taken into account. Are both default and confirmed value zero no attainment will be calculated.
E.buttonTextPP02_2_1: An operation is faster when the confirmed value is below the default value. Slower in the opposite case. If one of both values is not set, the case will be disregarded.
E.columnsPersonnel: Columns for the default and confirmed value for the personnel time
E.columnsDefaultPersonnel: Select the columns in which the default value and the corresponding unit for the personnel time are stored.
E.columnsConfirmedPersonnel: Select the columns in which the confirmed value and the corresponding unit for the personnel time are stored.
E.buttonTextPP04_0: Labor time is the time spent by a human working during an operation.
E.buttonTextPP04_1: The KPI target attainment for the labor time is calculated via this formula: default value per unit * (yield + scrap) / confirmed activity time.
E.buttonTextPP04_2: E.g. a default time of 3 min per unit, four units yield, one unit scrap and 20 min confirmed activity time result in an attainment of 75%.
E.buttonTextPP04_3:
Over multiple values the average is taken.

Notice: Only operations with an given default value will be taken into account. Are both default and confirmed value zero no attainment will be calculated.
E.CTcreateReleasePO: Cycle Times - Create Production Order to Release
E.buttonTextPP05_1_1:
The KPI scrap rate is calculated for each confirmation and is defined as the amount of scrap divided by the amount of scrap and yield:

scrap / (scrap + yield)
E.buttonTextPP05_1_2: If there are multiple values the average is stated.
E.buttonTextPP05_2: Operations with scrap describes the fraction of all operations for which a scrap has been reported .
E.CTReleaseSOP: Cycle Times - Release to Start of Production
E.buttonTextPP06_1_1: The troughput time for the subprocess is calculated as the period of time between the creation and the release of a production order. Over multiple value the median is taken.
E.buttonTextPP06_2_1: The total troughput time is calculated as the period of time between the first and the last activity of one production order. Over multiple value the median is taken.
E.buttonTextPP07_1_1: The manufacturing time is calculated as the period of time between the confirmed start and the confirmed end of the production of a production order.
E.buttonTextPP07_1_2: So it will be calculated only for completely manufactured production orders and not on a position basis. Over multiple value the median is taken.
E.buttonTextPP07_2_1: The total troughput time is calculated as the period of time between the first and the last activity of one production order. Over multiple value the median is taken.
E.infoautoPP00: Choose, which user types are used for automatic activities in your system. In general, 'B' stands for automatic and 'A' for manual activity.
E.CycleTimeDefine: Start and end activity of the subprocess
E.buttonTextPP06_1_1n: The troughput time for the subprocess is calculated as the period of time between the first and the last activtiy of the subprocess. Over multiple value the median is taken.

E.AnalysisDCM01ChallengeHeading: Why is it important to have a look on low value dispute cases?
E.AnalysisDCM01ChallengeText1: A dispute case accures if a customer doesn't want to settle his invoice or if you don't want to settle the invoice of a supplier. The root cause for it can be quality failure, delayed supply or several further reasons.
E.AnalysisDCM01ChallengeText2: The consequences of a dispute case are also diverse. For instance a disput case can cause a loss of money, customers or supply shortage. Furthermore each dispute case takes up a lot of time.
E.AnalysisDCM01ChallengeText3: In respect of the diverse consequences it is in doubt if it is meaningful to turn one's customers/ suppliers against oneself by a tedious procedure and also to invest one's own valuable time for a low value in dispute.
E.AnalysisDCM01ChallengeText4: With this analysis you can identify low value dispute cases and decide up to which value goodwill is advisable with respect to customer satisfaction and own time savings.
E.AnalysisDCM01Heading: Decrease the low value dispute rate
E.AnalysisDCM01PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that a decrease of the low value dispute rate is possible! Possible taking actions to decrease the low value dispute rate are shown in the sheet "Taking Action".
E.AnalysisDCM01PotentialText1: The greatest potential to save time and to keep up the customer satisfaction relies in not pursuing low value dispute cases.
E.AnalysisDCM01PotentialText2: Automate your process for low value dispute cases such as it accomplishes the demand without manual intervention.
E.AnalysisDCM01RootCauseQuestion: A classification of low value dispute cases
E.AnalysisDCM01RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisDCM01RootCauseText2: Here you can add statistics heavy information about root causes
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionImplementation1: Define a threshold under which a dispute case will not be pursued.
Make clear that every responsible person is aware of that threshold. Customers and suppliers do not need to know it.
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionImplementation2: Establish guidelines that explain what happens to low value dispute cases. For instance establish a counter to track how often such a low value dispute case appears per supplier/ customer and define consequences for regular occurence.
Or introduce a separate priorization for these cases.
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionImplementation3: Audit your previous processes and identify low value dispute cases. Identify customers/ suppliers that have disproportional many low value dispute cases and think about consequences.
Also look into for which materials these cases appear frequently.
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionImplementation4: Perform the Process Mining analysis frequently. Compare your results easily with previous audits and find out if you’re improved.
To save valuable time try to automise the dispute case process as far as possible.
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionObjective1: Save time and keep up the customer satisfaction
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionObjective2: Increase awareness of the correct process procedure
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionObjective3: Prevent the occurence of low value dispute cases
E.AnalysisDCM01TakingActionText1: Here you can add trends overtime or benchmarks to see the results over a period of time.
E.CostsPerLowValueDispute: Costs per low value dispute case
E.AnalysisDCM03ChallengeHeading: What do Multi Hops in the Dispute Case Process mean? Why is it important?
E.AnalysisDCM03ChallengeText1: As it is the aim to resolve the dispute cases that come in in a timely manner, it is important to ensure correct assignments to the responsible problem solving group at the first attempt.
E.AnalysisDCM03ChallengeText2: In this context, a multi hop takes place if a dispute case is assigned more than once after creation. Such reassignments lengthen the process unnecessarily and cost money.
E.AnalysisDCM03ChallengeText3: The average number of multi hops can differ across countries or configurations and can be especially related to certain subcategories.
E.AnalysisDCM03ChallengeText4: With the help of process mining, multi hops can be spotted easily and quickly. Provided with these unique insights, you can optimize the Dispute Case Management process to save time and money by effectively reducing these causes of inefficiencies.
E.AnalysisDCM03Heading: Analyzing Multi Hops in the Dispute Case Management
E.AnalysisDCM03KPIText1: Share of Multi Hop dispute cases
E.AnalysisDCM03PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that a reduction  of multi hop dispute cases is possible! And this calculation does not yet take an increasing customer satisfaction into account.
E.AnalysisDCM03PotentialText1: The greatest potential to save time and to keep up the customer satisfaction relies in avoiding Multi Hop dispute cases.
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseClassDefinition1: Correct assignment of dispute cases is critical in order to ensure quick resolution and high customer satisfaction. Assigning tickets to the wrong departments leads to re-routings and inefficiencies.
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseClassDefinition1_2: Celonis helps you to easily identify those cases and their root causes.
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseClassDefinition2: Departments with many reassignments may be inefficient and a closer look should be taken at them.
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseClassDefinition3: Inefficient communication between departments about the nature of the cases can lead to reassignments.
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseQuestion: A classification of Multi Hop dispute cases
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisDCM03RootCauseText2: Here you can add statistics heavy information about root causes
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionImplementation1: Quickly spot multi hop dispute cases (dispute cases that passed to more than two processors). Identify configurations and processors which are typically related to reassignments.
Find reasons for incorrect assignments to avoid them in the future.
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionImplementation2: Compare reassignments for all processors and categories and identify weaknesses. Create process steps (e.g. automated workflows) to mitigate these weaknesses.
Implement the process steps to ensure fast dispute case resolution.
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionObjective1: Speed up dispute case resolution and raise customer satisfaction
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionObjective2: Ensure dispute case resolution time to be as short as possible for all future cases
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionQuestion: What are useful measures to decrease Multi Hops?
E.AnalysisDCM03TakingActionText1: Here you can add trends overtime or benchmarks to see the results over a period of time.

E.settingMultiHopActivities: Define which activities are Multi Hop activities. To calculate the rate correctly, please make sure that not only a reassignment, but also the original assignment activity is selected.
E.AnalysisDCM04ChallengeHeading: Why do dispute cases occur? Where is their origin?
E.AnalysisDCM04ChallengeText1: The easiest way to deal with dispute cases is to not let them occur. If no dispute cases arise, customers are satisfied and no time and respectively money is wasted.
E.AnalysisDCM04ChallengeText2: To pave the way for this result, it is important to look into the origins of the existing dispute cases.
E.AnalysisDCM04ChallengeText3: By knowing the reason and the origin of a dispute case, you can address it directly and prevent it from arising in the future. As there are always causes that seem to be unavoidable in the first place,
E.AnalysisDCM04ChallengeText4: the best is to address first the ones that can be avoided by implementing relatively easy solutions. Be aware that in a perfect scenario no causes are unavoidable.
E.AnalysisDCM04Heading: Analyzing the origin of Dispute Cases
E.AnalysisDCM04PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that a decrease dispute cases is possible! Possible taking actions to decrease the amount of dispute cases are shown in the sheet "Taking Action".
E.AnalysisDCM04PotentialText1: The greatest potential to save time and to keep up the customer satisfaction relies in avoiding dispute cases at all by implementing measures to avoid the root causes, even for those that seem unavoidable in the first place.
E.AnalysisDCM04RootCauseQuestion: A classification of the origin of dispute cases
E.AnalysisDCM04RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisDCM04RootCauseText2: Here you can add statistics heavy information about root causes
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionImplementation1: Analyse if a root cause appears mostly for only one customer or category or does it appear for several customers/ categories.

Approach the customer directly to find a solution, if the issue mostly appears in the trade with him.  If the issue appears for several customers, have a deeper look into the internal processes, find the lack and fix it.
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionImplementation2: Think about the root causes and measures to solve them. Even if they seem unavoidable like 'Approval pending' or 'Missing information on invoice' there can be a solution: analyse and speed up your approval process/
remind your suppliers directly when ordering how a correct invoice needs to look like. Try to downsize your rate of unavoidable dispute cases.
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionImplementation3: Write the root causes and the measures to adress them down. Make the document available for everyone that could be responsible or help to implement the measures.
Speak to the respective departments in person to hihlight the importance of the topic.
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionImplementation4: Follow up the improvement process. Does the amount of dispute cases decrease? Which root causes appear less often? Which measures have been effective?
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionObjective3: Clear understanding of the approach within the company
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionObjective4: Avoid the occurance of the root causes in the future
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionQuestion: What are useful measures to decrease dispute cases?
E.AnalysisDCM04TakingActionText1: Here you can add trends overtime or benchmarks to see the results over a period of time.

E.AnalysisPSA01ChallengeHeading: Why is on-time delivery so important?
E.AnalysisPSA01ChallengeText1: On-time delivery is defined as the delivery of goods by the supplier within a defined tolerance time for the delivery, typically 3 days before the due date up to the due date itself.
E.AnalysisPSA01ChallengeText2: On-time delivery is vital in today’s world of business for several reasons. First, for most companies, the internal production planning and scheduling is dependent on the reliability of timely deliveries by the supplier.
E.AnalysisPSA01ChallengeText3: The worst-case scenario is a production downtime, which are very costly and have the consequence that the company is not able to meet customer demands in the subsequent supply chain and order-to-cash process.

E.AnalysisPSA04RootCauseClass3: Belated order creation within correction time-span
E.AnalysisPSA04RootCauseClassDefinition1: A order is generally classified in this category if its planned delivery date lays in the future with more days than defined in the short-notice threshold.
E.AnalysisPSA04RootCauseClassDefinition2: A order is generally classified in this category if its planned delivery date lays within the defined short-notice threshold.
E.AnalysisPSA04RootCauseClassDefinition3: A order is generally classified in this category if its planned delivery date lays before the order creation date but within the correction-threshold.
E.AnalysisPSA04RootCauseClassDefinition4: A order is generally classified in this category if its planned delivery date lays before the short-notice-correction threshold.

E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseQuestion: Why aren’t deliveries on time in the purchase-to-pay process?
E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseReasonsText1: Here you can include information about reasons generating the main issues in the process.
E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseText1: The root causes for a low On-Time-Delivery Ratio can be classified as follows.
E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseText2: Set the data of data extract or Today()
E.AnalysisPSA01RootCauseTitle: Classifications for delivery status of Schedule Lines:
E.AnalysisPSA01TakingActionImplementation1: Make sure that every site has easy access for booking goods receipts into the enterprise system. Train personnel and make sure every site adheres to booking goods receipts on the same day the goods arrive.
E.AnalysisPSA01TakingActionImplementation2: Contact suppliers you have identified in the analysis and point out your definition of On-Time Delivery and that you expect an improvement.
E.AnalysisPSA01TakingActionImplementation3: Contractually agree to a penalty system with consistently late suppliers. Track On-Time-Delivery KPIs and if the respective suppliers fail to uphold due delivery dates, they will have to pay a penalty charge.
This charge is typically determined as an amount in % of the invoice. In case penalty charges already exist in your company, consider increasing the amount of the charges for these specific vendors.
E.AnalysisPSA01TakingActionImplementation4: Contact the appropriate department with a list of deleted SLs, as the system takes these into account as “late” deliveries, thereby distorting the results of the On-Time Delivery rate. Delete these in order to improve your calculation ratios.
E.AnalysisPSA01TakingActionMeasure1: Enable all sites to book a goods receipt

E.OTDMotivationHead: Why are violations of On-Time-Delivery so critical?
E.OTDMotivationText: On-Time-Delivery in the Order-to-Cash process impacts the efficiency of operations as well as customer satisfaction, loyalty, and revenue. Organizations typically have a high number of variations and exceptions within the Order-to-Cash process, which result in high order-processing costs. If confirmed delivery dates are not met, customer satisfaction is negatively affected.
E.OFMotivationHead: Why is the determination of the Order Frequency so crucial?
E.OFMotivationText:
Analyzing the frequency of sales orders sets the focus on few high-frequent buyers who account for most of all orders.
Primary objective of sales departments is the maximization of sales volume which can be achieved by increasing the amount of sales orders and/or by decreasing the costofgoods sold.
E.TouchlessOrdersO2C23DefineManualActiviti: Deselect activities which should not be used for the calculation of 'Touchless Orders'. The table on the right can be used to identify 'always manual' activities.
E.FTRMotivationHead: Why are violations of First-Time-Right so critical?
E.FTRMotivationText:
First-Time-Right evaluates how well your purchasing process really works - by calculating how often purchase orders run through without being touched by unwanted activities like rework or changes.
As a smooth processing within the sales is a mandatory requirement for the maintenance of the daily operation, it is important to ensure a prompt delivery of ordered materials and avoid rework activities as these are often the root of manual effort and slow the process down.
E.CTMotivationHead: Why is the determination of the Cycle Time so crucial?
E.CTMotivationText: The cycle time of activities within the Order-to-Cash process provide critical information on the efficiency of order management. With regard to a company's net working capital and liquidity, it is highly relevant to reduce the time it takes to collect receivables. High cycle times can be due to inefficient internal processing as well as problematic customers.

E.GIMotivationHead: Why is the Goods Issue without Invoice Creation so critical?
E.GIMotivationText: Delivering goods without sending customers the corresponding invoice may lead to severe income losses. Identifying the main causes of missing invoices could show high potential for improvement.

E.IPMotivationHead: Why is the identification of Incomplete Processes so crucial?
E.IPMotivationText: An important aspect in sales efficiency is the avoidance of orders that are stuck in a process step as they slow down the whole process.
E.SoDMotivationText: Segregation of Duties means that certain combinations of tasks or activities should not be conducted by the same person. The challenge of achieving this is to identify relevant cases where SoD is violated as these are one of the top contributors for fraudulent activities in a company.

E.AnalysisOPP07Heading: Identify your Born to Win Opportunities
E.AnalysisOPP07ChallengeText1: Born to Win is a term used to classifiy opportunities which are created very late within the CRM process and are therefore very likely to end as closed won opportunities. This can be problematic for various reasons.
E.AnalysisOPP07ChallengeText2: A high Born-to-Win rate could indicate that many opportunities are not documented properly, either deliberately in order to raise ones conversion rate, or as a result of poor documentation overall.
E.AnalysisOPP07PotentialText1: This analysis will help you identify where Born To Win opportunities occur in your CRM Lead-to-Quote process and how they can be avoided.
E.ColorThresholdsForBornToWinRate: Color Thresholds for Born to Win Rate
E.CutoffDaysText: Define the maximum number of days between Create Opportunity and Set Opportunity to 'Closed as Won' to be considered as Born to Win
E.CutoffProbText: Define the minimum probability percentage that a Opportunity must be created with to be considered as Born to Win
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionTitle: What are useful measures to decrease the Born-To-Win rate?
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionObjective1: Appeal to employers so that they are aware of the wrong usage.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionObjective2: Get employees to know about the correct usage right from the start.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionObjective3: Use incentives to reward employees when using the CRM system properly.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionObjective4: Get employees to completely understand how the CRM solution works.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionImplementation1: Discuss the topic in a team huddle. Send reminders via e-mail.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionImplementation2: Make the Born-to-Win problematic a topic in the onboarding procedure when discussing the CRM process.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionImplementation3: Give rewards for well documented opportunities.
E.AnalysisOPP07TakingActionImplementation4: Offer mandatory CRM trainings for all employees using the CRM system.
E.AnalysisOPP07ClassificationInfoHeader2: Born to Win due to short time to conversion
E.AnalysisOPP07ClassificationInfoHeader3: Born to Win due to high initial probability
E.AnalysisOPP07ClassificationInfoText1: All opportunities with both a short time to conversion and a high initial probability are classified as Born to Win.
E.AnalysisOPP07ClassificationInfoText2: Opportunities which only display a short time to conversion are classified in this category.
E.AnalysisOPP07ClassificationInfoText3: Opportunities with a regular time to conversion, but are entered with a high initial probability are classified in this category.

E.AnalysisCM07ChallengeHeading: Why is adhereing to milestone commitments important?
E.AnalysisCM07ChallengeText1: Having a low milestone fulfillment rate indicates that internal processes are taking too long or that the defined target times are too ambitious.
E.AnalysisCM07ChallengeText2: Especially for the first reason, it is important to find out the root causes why the desired target times can not be met,
E.AnalysisCM07ChallengeText3: as a low milestone fulfillment rate can have several negative internal and external impacts.
E.AnalysisCM07ChallengeText4: Typical negative effects are having unsatisfied customers or a decrease in employee satisfaction.
E.AnalysisCM07KPIText1: The Milestone Fulfillment Rate can be calculated as follows
E.AnalysisCM07PotentialSmallText1: * Our experience shows that increasing the Milestone Fulfillment Rate is possible and leads to a very good customer loayality!
E.AnalysisCM07PotentialText1: Identifying root causes for violated commitments allows to establish improvement measures in order to implement a smooth case management process ensuring a high customer retention.
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseClass1: Target dates are set too ambitious
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseClassDefinition1: The defined target dates are set too ambitious. This means, even thoug the milestone fulfillment rate is low, the process can run smoothly
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseClassDefinition2: Employees lose time understanding the customer request as their input contains not all needed information to process at in a adequate way. This could include that the customer needs be contacted to provide needed information
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseClassDefinition3: There are too many customer requests coming in so that the existing customer support can't handle all requests within the target time
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseClassDefinition4: The case managemnet process is conducted in a very unstructured and unorganized manner having a high variation
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseQuestion: What are typical root causes for Violated Milestones
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseText1: Here you can add the classification of root causes in your process
E.AnalysisCM07RootCauseText2: Here you can add statistics heavy information about root causes
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionImplementation1: Start with milestones which are violated very frequently. Check whether those often violated milestones are understood by the employees in the right way. One possibility to provide more information for the user could be to add info-buttons.
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionImplementation2: Compare the set target times with the actual processing time and use the drilldowns to find out, why there are differences. Eventually, the set times are too optimisitc and it makes sense to adapt the set deadlines.
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionImplementation3: Analyze whether the input forwarded by the customer provides all the information necessary to process the case in an adequate manner.
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionImplementation33: To keep it more simple for the customer, define only a few required fields that are essential for employees to process the case and do not demand not needed information.
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionImplementation4: Develop and roll-out a standardized process having not many exceptions. This ensures  working in a very structured way and allows to make more precise estimations about the duration of certain steps.
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionObjective1: Identify accumulations of violated milestones and who is responsible for the violations
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionObjective2: Analzye whether the set target times are realistic
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionObjective3: Support the customer to get complete inquiries
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionObjective4: Optimize and speed up the case processing by standardization
E.AnalysisCM07TakingActionQuestion: What are useful measures to increase the Milestone Fulfillment Rate?

E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeHeading: Why is having a high First-Time-Right Rate so important?
E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeText1: Case Management quality means that the service organization is able to process cases in a very structured and organized way, at the right place and at the right time.
E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeText2: In that context, an important aspect is the avoidance of rework activities as these are often the root of manual effort and slow the process down.
E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeText3: In order to ensure a smooth and fast case processing, it is of great interest to identify cases that were correctly processed at the first time and adapt the handling applied in these cases.
E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeText4: The goal of this First-Time-Right analysis is to evaluate how well your case management process really works
E.AnalysisCM08ChallengeText5: - by calculating how often cases are closed without executing a process step twice meaning that there was something not implemented accurately the first time.
E.AnalysisCM08KPIText1: The First-Time-Right Rate can be calculated as follows
E.AnalysisCM08PotentialSmallText1: * Our experience shows that increasing the First-Time-Right-Rate is possible! And this calculation does not yet take an increasing customer- and employee satisfaction into account.
E.AnalysisCM08PotentialText1: With the help of process mining, First-Time-Right cases can be spotted easily and quickly. Provided with these unique insights, businesses can optimize their case process to save time and money by effectively reducing causes of inefficiencies

E.AnalysisCM08TakingActionImplementation1: Create a guideline showing the different steps of the case management process and how to evaluate these, either with screenshots or by recording your screen for a tutorial video.
E.AnalysisCM08TakingActionImplementation2: Organize brief training sessions and demonstrate how to implement the best practice and how to evaluate current cases
E.AnalysisCM08TakingActionImplementation3: Use Celonis to continuously identify first-time-right rates and send out automated reports to all involved parties on a monthly basis with the help of Celonis Stories.

E.AnalysisCM06ChallengeHeading: Why is knowing about a case's Time at a Customer important?
E.AnalysisCM06ChallengeText1: In order to ensure a smooth and fast case processing, it can be essential to be aware and incorporate customer's characteristics and wishes in the own process.
E.AnalysisCM06ChallengeText2: Not knowing about how long you typically wait on feedback of a customer can have several drawbacks such as underutilized capacities.
E.AnalysisCM06ChallengeText3: The goal of this analysis is to evaluate how long the case actually stays on customer side - by adding up the time difference between all activities that indicate a customer intervention and their successor step.
E.AnalysisCM06KPIText1: The Time at Customer can be calculated as follows
E.AnalysisCM06PotentialSmallText1: * Our experience shows that improving the capacity utilization is possible saving a lot of money! And this calculation does not yet take an increasing customer satisfaction and retention rates into account.
E.AnalysisCM06PotentialText1: With the help of Process Mining, "slow" and "quick" customers can be identified easily. Provided with these unique insights, business and IT can optimize their capacity planning and  set up an efficient case processing process.
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition1: All cases that were less than 1 day at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition2: All cases that were around  1 day at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition3: All cases that were between 2-3 days at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition4: All cases that were between 4-6 days at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition5: All cases that were between 7-14 days at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition6: All cases that were between 15-30 days at a customer
E.AnalysisCM06RootCauseClassDefinition7: All cases that more than 30 days at a customer

E.AnalysisCM06TakingActionImplementation1: Create an overview how long a case typically stays on customer side. It might not necessarily be a diasadvantage when a customer needs some time to analze your measures, but it facilitates the internal capacity planning.
E.AnalysisCM06TakingActionImplementation11: Knowing that your customer needs typically around 30 days, you can keep capacities for this case and quickly process it increasing the customer satisfaction
E.AnalysisCM06TakingActionImplementation2: Define a fixed threshold after which you remember the customer that you are waiting on him to further process the case.
E.AnalysisCM06TakingActionObjective1: Adapt the case processing process by learning customer's characteristics
E.AnalysisCM06TakingActionObjective2: Ensure that the customers remember that the responsibility is on their side

E.IntroOperations: In order to guarantee excellent corporate performance, negative deviations in daily business should be counteracted immediately to prevent larger harm. Keep track of your latest operational KPIs and developments and conduct deeper analysis of the root causes in case of conspicuous deviatons. Let us get started!
E.CalcFirstContactResolution: Calculated by counting the tickets that are resolved directly after opening.
E.CalcOpenTickets: Calculated by counting the tickets that are open as of today.
E.CalcTickets: Calculated by counting the amount of tickets.
E.Creator: Creator
E.IntroQuestionMH: Why is a reduction of tickets with multi hops so important?
E.IntroMH1: Multi hops in the assignment and processing of tickets slow down the business efficiency as they typically involve rework activities.
E.IntroMH2: At the same time, the significant manual effort involved in the reassignment of the tickets also significantly increases process costs.
E.IntroMH3: Therefore, it is in every company's best interest to minimize the multi hops of tickets as much as possible.
E.IntroMH4: Let us get started to analyze multi hops and how to reduce them within this analysis.
E.transformationPotentialText1: To provide you with an easy-to-use quantification of the business potential, we use full-time equivalent (FTE) based calculation
E.transformationPotentialText2: that examines the number of manual Multi Hop activities, the time per change and the resulting cost impact.
E.pvgtext: Decide if you want to analyze Multi Hops from a Person or from a Group Perspective
E.perHigh: Define the percentage above which the automation rate is acceptable
E.perLow: Define the percentage below which the automation rate is seen critical
E.IntroQuestionCT: Why is a reduce of cycle times so important?
E.IntroTextCT1: Cycle times in the subprocesses time to react and time to resolve a ticket provide critical information on the organisation's IT service management efficiency.
E.IntroTextCT2: Reducing theses cycle times can not only improve the efficiency within your organization but also increase your customer satisfaction.
E.IntroTextCT3: Therefore, it is in every company's best interest to minimize the cycle time of tickets as much as possible.
E.IntroTextCT4: Let us get started to analyze cycle times of tickets and how to improve them within this analysis.
E.lowCT: Define the number above which the CT is seen critical
E.highCT: Define the number below which the CT is seen acceptable
E.startActText: Start Activity for the process of resolving a ticket
E.endActText: End Activity for the process of resolving a ticket
E.transformationPotentialTextCT: that examines the number of manual activities, the time per change and the resulting cost impact.
E.prioTicketsGoal: Deal with the high priority and high impact tickets first, in order to achieve a high customer satisfaction.
E.prioTicketsStep1: Define criteria for the prioritization of tickets.
E.prioTicketsStep2: Define criteria for the impact of the ticket on your organization's business.
E.catTicketsText: Identify and avoid long runner to reduce the median total cycle time.
E.catTicketsStep1: Drilldown on a detailed level e.g. on company, location or assignment group level to identify long runner.
E.catTicketsStep2: Have a look on connections in the process explorer that take particular long.
E.intKnowText: Standardize your processes to gain transparency.
E.intKnowStep1: Identify the most common processes, categorize them and develop a best practice manual for each category.
E.intKnowStep2: Recommend automatically articles/ best practices from your knowledge base based on the topic of a tickett.
E.DefineAutoNames: Choose which user names are used for automatic activities in your system.
E.OpenActivity: Activity to open up a new ticket.
E.InfoClassificationsOperationsClick: Click here for more information about the classifications
E.InfoClassificationsState: State Classification: A ticket is open if it has no resolving date. 'Reopened' means that a ticket status has been changed from status 'resolved' to 'in process'. All other tickets are marked as closed.
E.SLAFullfillmentPerPriority: SLA Fullfillment Rate by Ticket Priority
E.InfoClassificationsLevel: Service Level Classification:  A First Contact Resolution is accomplished if the incident can be solved directly after opening. All other service levels relate to the ones set in the settings.
E.DetailsSettings: For details, see the Settings Sheet.
E.ExplTimeToReact: The average time till the first reaction to a ticket.
E.ExplTimeToResolve: The average time between opening and solving a ticket is considered in this calculation.
E.ExplCT: The median time of a ticket in the system is calculated.
E.ClickCT: Click here for more information about reasons that lead to long cycle times.
E.RCAnalysisCT: The root cause analysis looks at tickets with high impact and high priority where impact ranges from 1 to 9 with 1 as the highest and priority ranges from 1 to 4 with 1 as the highest. This leads to a multiplicated score per ticket from 1 to 39, whereof 1 to 12 is classified as 'HIGH', 13 to 24 as 'MEDIUM' and 25 to 39 as 'LOW'.
E.ExplTicketsWithMH: Number of tickets that passed at least through one reassignment.
E.ExplRC: The root cause analysis looks at the appearance of Multi Hops from different perspectives. Drilldown to a deeper level to see where the share of Multi Hops is high.
E.ClickInfoMH: Click here for more information about the Multi-Hop root cause analysis.
E.revIncidentText: Ensure your ticket cluster are up to date and clear regulated.
E.revIncidentImpl1: Define clear rules to distingush tickets based on content, priority and impact. Moreover find a solution to handle tickets that do not fit in any category. E.g. these tickets are assigned to a special group or evenly allocated over the teams.
E.revIncidentImpl2: Check the defined rules on a regular base to ensure that they are still valid.
E.revIncidentImpl3: Explorer which tickets are referred to a more expensive, downstream support group, although they should be resolved by the first level support.
E.revIncidentImpl4: This slows down the resolution time and costs extra money. You can filter different dimensions and see respectively in the process explorerer of the assignment sheet which support groups are affected for which topics and how often. By directed trainings and management you can thereby raise the First-Time-Right rate of the first level support.
E.autoIncidentText: Configure the system to automatically assign and/ or response to tickets.
E.autoIncidentImpl1: If possible automate the ticket assignment respectively to the preconfigured assignment rules.
E.autoIncidentImpl2: When assessing the tickets for the assignment, identify most common tickets and automate the response using response templates.
E.defIncidentText: Standardize the communication way of how tickets are handled within your organization.
E.defIncidentImpl1: Define standards for the communication concerning tickets. Are you using comments or notes? What are information a comment/ note/ ticket needs to include? How do you communicate issues with a ticket?
E.defIncidentImpl2: Communicate the cummunication guideline within the company and define responsibilities.
E.sta2TicketsText: Save time and money by avoiding unwanted activities.
E.sta2TicketsStep1: Benchmark your process for different companies, locations or  business services. Compare e.g. two different locations. Which one has more reopened tickets? What is different in the other location? What may influence this number?
E.sta2TicketsStep2: Define standard process steps of a ticket. Moreover decide which is desired bahavior of a ticket and which is not. Identify a target process, activities that may occur additionally as well as activities that should be avoided.
E.sta2TicketsStep3: Communicate the process definition within the company and define responsibilities.
E.cat2TicketsText: Define categories for your tickets to improve your internal efficiciency and avoid ticket occurence.
E.cat2TicketsStep1: Define and/or refine existing ticket categories.
E.cat2TicketsStep2: Find root causes for the occurrence of tickets in the respective categories and try to solve them in a long run.
E.cat2TicketsStep3: Automate steps in the respective process for each category.
E.stra2TicketsText: Evolve a strategy to handle information stored in tickets.
E.stra2TicketsStep1: You are able to recognize general disturbances early by a continuous data load. Proposed solutions can be worked out proactively and therefore the amount of tickets can be reduced in general.
E.stra2TicketsStep2: Integrate customer knowledge and problems to improve your product development process or service offering.
E.AnalysisCM01ChallengeText1: Multihops refer to change request reassignments due to inability or unwillingness of the original assignee to complete the task.
E.AnalysisCM01ChallengeText2: The occurance of multihops have a negative effect on the resolution time of the change request process.
E.AnalysisCM01TAHeading: What are useful measures to reduce Multihops?
E.AnalysisCM01TAChallengeText1: Improve the competence of your change request assignees by means of additional training and education.
E.AnalysisCM01TAChallengeText2: Monitor the working capacity and current workload of the your request assignees to avoid overloading them.
E.AnalysisCM01TAChallengeText3: Identify the key competences and weaknesses of your task assignees and assignment groups to optimize your assignment policies.
E.AnalysisCM01TAChallengeText4: Identify root causes for change request subsets associated with unusually high reassignment rates.
E.AnalysisCM02TAHeading: What are useful measures to reduce Resolution Time?
E.AnalysisCM02TAChallengeText1: Implement request-monitoring and highlight requests that are overdue.
E.AnalysisCM02TAChallengeText2: Identify long-running requests and eliminate the reasons causing the overly long duration.
E.AnalysisCM02TAChallengeText3: Eliminate unnecessary additional tasks and approvals.
E.AnalysisCM02TAChallengeText4:
Implement company-wide standardized policies for submittion of change requests to ensure that everyone involved in the change request 
immediately have an understanding of implementation plan, business justification and other change request details.
E.AverageResolutionTimeForChangesIncluding: Average Resolution Time for Changes Including Activity
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionText1: Here you can add trends overtime or benchmarks to see the results over a period of time.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionQuestion: What are useful measures to decrease Multi-Hops?
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective3: Facilitate communication between allocator and agent to minimize multiple reassignments
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective2: Reduce additional effort needed for reassignment of ticket
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective1: Directly assign correct agent to a ticket
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_1: By improving the communication between the ticket allocator and the agent, incorrect assignments can be uncovered and thus avoided in the future.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_2: Also, a transparent overview of every agent's expertise and capacity can help to optimize the ticket assignments.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation2: By automating the ticket (re-)assignment process significant time can be saved by avoiding manual reassignments. Additonally, artificial intelligence can be implemented to improve this automated reassignment process over time.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation1_1: By implementing an intelligent algorithm which focuses on the correct assignment of tickets to agents, reassignments later in the process can be avoided.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation1_2: Furthermore, this has an impact on the total process time of a ticket and thus improves the customer satisfaction overall.

E.AnalysisCSPotentialText1: Here you can write information about potential savings
E.AnalysisCSPotentialSmallText1: * Our experience shows that a reduction of late deliveries makes savings of up to Var8 € possible! And this calculation does not yet take an increasing customer satisfaction and retention rates into account.
E.AnalysisCSKPIText1: Here you can include information about your main KPIs.

E.Analysis_SN_CS_Text1: This Customer Service Analysis aims at uncovering the effect of so called Multi-Hops, i.e. the change of an assigned ticket from one agent to another.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Text2: These Multi-Hops are the result of an inefficient ticket assignment process which costs time and money.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Text3: Therefore, this analysis quickly highlights the most expensive reassignment paths in order to tackle these inefficiencies precisely.
E.MoreInfo: Click here for more information about reasons that lead to Multi-Hop assignments
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Cycle Time_Text1: The Cycle Time for every Ticket in this analysis is calculated for three different scenarios: Time 2 React, Time 2 Resolve and Total Cycle Time.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Cycle Time_Text2: For the Time 2 React, the duration from the ticket creation to the point where the ticket is edited for the first time is calculated. For the Time 2 Resolve the duration from the ticket creation to the ticket resolution is computed.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Cycle Time_Text3: The Total Cycle Time corresponds to the total duration from the ticket creation to the last action performed on the ticket.
E.ExplTotalCycleTime: Avergae time of a ticket in the system
E.MoreInfoCycleTime: Click here for more information about reasons that lead to high Cycle Times
E.MoreInfoCycleTimeText: The root cause analysis looks at the appearance of high cycle times for different levels of importance.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Cycle Time_Text4: Overall, the goal of this analysis is to uncover tickets that take overly long to be processed and eliminate them for a more efficient process.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective1_CycleTi: Deal first with tickets that have a high impact and high priority to achieve a higher customer satisfaction.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective2_CycleTi: Implement Ticket-Monitoring and highlight tickets which are overdue.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective3_CycleTi: Identify Long runner tickets and eliminate the reasons causing the overly long duration.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation2_1_: Use your ticket assignment tool to track processing times.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation2_2_: Define processing time limits to mark tickets as overdue.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_1_: Use Ticket Monitoring to identify highly overdue tickets.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_2_: Figure out bottlenecks causing the tickets to be delayed and eliminate them.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionQuestion_CycleTime: What are useful measures to improve your operations?
E.TransformationPotentialExplained: The transformation potential is calculated based on the  variables entered in the settings sheet.
E.ExplAllTickets: This number reflects all tickets which are considered in this analysis.
E.ExplOpenTickets: This number reflects all tickets which have not been set to the status 'Resolved'.
E.ExplReopenedTickets: This number reflects all tickets which have been set to the status 'Resolved' and afterwards were marked as 'Ticket in Progress'.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Operations_Text1: The operations analysis takes a closer look at three specific KPIs related to each other: Number of tickets overall, number of open tickets and number of tickets that were opened again after being solved.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Operations_Text2: By digging deeper into these numbers, inefficiencies and irregularities within the standard process can be identified.
E.Analysis_SN_CS_Operations_Text3: Especially, the reopening of tickets is a sign of inefficiency as the ticket was not handled correctly in the first place.
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective1_Operati: Identify reasons within the process that lead to the reopening of tickets
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective2_Operati: Benchmark different ticket types based on user name, type of subclass and type of contact
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionObjective3_Operati: Standardize the process as much as possible
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation1_1_: Figure out what happens to tickets which are reopened
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation1_2_: Identify reasons why the process steps performed after the ticket was resolved where not conducted earlier and eliminate them
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation2_1_: Benchmark the different ticket characteristics and figure out the most efficient process patterns
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation2_2_: Create best practice examples from your benchmarks
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_1_: Create standardized patterns for the handling of every ticket, subcase and task based on your best practice examples
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionImplementation3_2_: Ensure that the customer service agents adhere to the defined patterns and justify deviations
E.AnalysisCSTakingActionQuestion_Operation: How can we improve our operations?
E.transformationpotentialExplainedExecutiv: To provide you with an easy-to-use quantification of the transformation potential, we use a calculation based on the Transformation Unit you choose.

E.AnalysisP2O40ChallengeHeading: Why is the segregation of duties so important?
E.AnalysisP2O40Heading: Improve the segregation of duties rate
E.AnalysisP2O40KPIText1: The violated SOD Ratio of the two selected activities is calculated by dividing the PO items with violation of SOD by the number of total purchase order items of the two selected activities.
E.AnalysisP2O40PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that an improvement of the segregation of duties is possible! Possible taking actions to improve the segregation of duties are shown in the sheet "Taking Action".
E.AnalysisP2O40PotentialText1: The strength of SOD controls relies in the fact that there are at least three different individuals involved in every transaction.
E.AnalysisP2O40PotentialText2: When considering if the processes are properly segregated, the key parts to consider are custody, authorization and record keeping.
E.AnalysisP2O40RootCauseQuestion: A classification of Purchase Orders without segregation of duties
E.AnalysisP2O40RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes
E.AnalysisP2O40RootCauseText2: Here you can add statistics heavy information about root causes
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionImplementation1: Ensure that every single employee belongs to a specific department and function. No job role should contain incompatible duties.
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionImplementation2: Create a documentation in accordance with your company standards.
Make the guidelines available for daily work. Every employee has to know exactly what she/he is doing and also what she/he is not allowed to do.
Determine an owner for the document, who will make it available to new employees.
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionImplementation3: Audit your previous processes and identify purchases without a segregation of duties.
Define the reasons for the suspicious processes and identify any fraudulent conduct.
Give training sessions to avoid any future mistakes.
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionImplementation4: Perform the Process Mining analysis frequently.
Compare your results easily with previous audits and find out if you’re improved.
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionObjective2: Increase awareness of the correct process procedure
E.AnalysisP2O40TakingActionText1: Here you can add trends overtime or benchmarks to see the results over a period of time.
E.AnalysisP2O37Heading: Robotic Process Automation - Assess your P2O process for the suitability of RPA solutions
E.AnalysisP2O37Question: Why is a suitability assessment for RPA solutions important?
E.AnalysisP2O06ChallengeHeading: Why Is Improve Automation Rate So Important?
E.AnalysisP2O06ChallengeText1: Automation of activities has many advantages over manual execution. Company with high automation rate could benefit from time and cost saving as well as faster
E.AnalysisP2O06ChallengeText2: processing and reduce of manual entry errors. To take an Example, in the purchasing department of a company, a higher automation rate in the process of creating
E.AnalysisP2O06ChallengeText3: and approving purchase requests could significantly reduce inefficiency and manual work.
E.AnalysisP2O06Heading: Minimize the number of manual changes and rework
E.AnalysisP2O06PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that a reduction of manual conducted activities is possible! Possibile ways of reducing the amount of manual conducted activities are shown in this analysis.
E.AnalysisP2O06PotentialText1: To provide you with an easy-to-use quantification of the business potential, we use a full-time equivalent (FTE) based calculation that examines the number of manual
E.AnalysisP2O06PotentialText2: created activity, the time per change and the resulting cost impact.
E.AnalysisP2O06KPIText1: The result below shows only the automation rate of the certain activity defined by the user in the “settings” sheet. The result is calculated by dividing the
E.AnalysisP2O06KPIText2: automation cases of this distinct activity by the total amount of this activity.
E.AP2O44KPIDescription02: Digital Fit: The average manual touches per PO Item
E.AP2O44KPIDescription03: Case Automation Rate: The percentage of fully  automated PO Item processing
E.AP2O44KPIDescription04: Activities per Case Automation Rate: Returns the average percentage of automated activities per PO Item
E.AP2O44KPIDescription05: Activity Automation Rate: Returns the Average percentage of automated Activities.
E.AP2O44KPIDescription06: The Automation Rate KPI can be adjusted in the settings sheet.
E.AP2O44ExplanationText01: Switch  on Classification to separate Activities which are automated from those which are not automated.  (Activities which are white-listed in the settings sheet are excluded from the bucketing.)
E.AP2O44ExplanationText02: By using this classification option, differences in process flow can be spotted in the Celonis Process Explorer.
E.AnalysisP2O08Heading: Increase the use of contracts  to ensure an efficient procurement process.
E.AnalysisP2O08ChallengeText1: Too many companies have troubles with signing and monitoring their contracts efficiently, resulting in high risks of supply shortcomings.
E.AnalysisP2O08ChallengeText2: It takes a lot of effort and research for strategic pruchasing to negotiate good contracts with well established suppliers. Not using these contracts is inefficient and incompliant.
E.AnalysisP2O08PotentialText1: Normally, prices can vary depending on different suppliers or the economic situation, with the use of contracts a company can increase the predictability of prices.
E.AnalysisP2O08PotentialText2: Also, procurement transactions become more efficient as fewer approvals are necessary.
E.AnalysisP2O08PotentialText3: A further positive effect of efficient contract usage at its optimum are aggregated orders and the ability to make use of economies of scale.
E.AnalysisP2O08KPIDevelopment: Development of Contract Usage over time
E.AnalysisP2O08RootCause01: Contract Usage with and w/o PR
E.AnalysisP2O08RootCause05: Contract Usage by Average PO Value
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionTitle: What are effective messures to increase Contract Usage in Procurement?
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionMeasure3: Check running times, prices and order volumes
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionObjective1: Negotiate and try to enter into new contracts with sustaining vendors
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionObjective2: Optimize Contract Usage and decrease single orders
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionObjective4: Reduce the amount of manual non-contract orders
E.AnalysisP2O08TakingActionImplementation0: Check your vendors with high values and low cycle times. This is an indicator for a potential contract.
In case you have set no contract with those vendors, contact the responsible contact person and negotiate about future contracts.
Check your orders and look for materials and services which are being ordered additionally to a sustaining contract with the same materials and service.
Look for materials and services which are part of a contract but in some cases ordered parallel from other vendors.
Incentivize the implementation of electronic contract usage for large customers.
Use the Transformation Centre to continuously evaluate Contract Usage  Rates and send out reports to all procurement managers on a regular basis

E.AnalysisP2O02ChallengeHeading: What are approvals in this context and why may they slow down the overall process?
E.P2O02ApprovalProcessDefinition: The approval activities are steps that are performed on requisition level in order to finalize the requisition request and create and order.
E.P2O02UseCaseDescription01: Purchase requisitions often have to pass extensive approval procedures. The purchase requisition approval process starting with the creation of a purchase requisition and ending with the creation of the purchase order requires high personnel and time resources.
E.P2O02UseCaseDescription03: One way to cut costs is by decreasing the cycle times associated with the approval procedures of purchase requisitions. As a smooth processing within the purchase is a mandatory requirement for the maintenance of the daily operation it is
E.P2O02UseCaseDescription04: important to ensure a prompt delivery of ordered materials. The avoidance of long cycle times associated with the release process are therefore essential.
E.AnalysisP2O02Heading: Reduce the Cycle Time of the Approval Process
E.AnalysisP2O02KPIText1: The median cycle time of the approval process is calculated by focusing on the timestamps of the respective activities. The relevant subprocess flows from:
E.AnalysisP2O02Name: Cycle Times - Process Start to Release Purchase Order
E.AnalysisP2O02PotentialSmallText1: *Our experience shows that a decrease of the cycle time is possible! Possible taking actions to decrease the cycle time are shown in the sheet "Taking Action".
E.AnalysisP2O02PotentialText1: To cut costs a decrease of the cycle times associated with the approval procedures of purchase requisitions is mandatory. One possibility is to avoid rework or another to speed up the approval process.
E.AnalysisP2O02RootCauseQuestion: A classification of the Approval Process
E.AnalysisP2O02RootCauseReasonsTitle: Possible reasons generating problem root causes

E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionImplementation1: Select multiple purchase requisitions and release or reject them at once.
E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionImplementation2: Get an overview of the approval strategies for different purchase requisition categories (e.g. categories by net order value). Identify purchase requisition categories with exaggerated approval strategies and adapt the approval strategy for those cases.

For instance, common purchase requisition items (the once with hich amount of cases) can become more regular with less approvals. Also, requisition items with low net order value do not need various approval steps. In addition, high amount of approval activities can be considered in order to decrease rework as well as un-necessary work.
E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionImplementation3: Create a guideline showing the different steps of purchase requisitions, either with screenshots or by recording your screen for a tutorial video.
Create a new folder as a kit for new purchasers, so that future employees will directly implement the best practice.
E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionImplementation4: Go into Ariba and check the system for the proper set up. In case you have no experience with the set up, contact the responsible purchaser or IT department with the issue.
E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionImplementation5: Use Celonis to evaluate the amount of approvals per purchase requisition item and send out reports to all responsible persons on a regular basis. Establish a continuous improvement process for making the approval process more lean and efficient.
E.AnalysisP2O02TakingActionMeasure4: Check the settings of your ERP system
